metadata.firstNLines:
This is a [Next.js](https://nextjs.org) project bootstrapped with [`create-next-app`](https://nextjs.org/docs/app/api-reference/cli/create-next-app).

## Getting Started

First, run the development server:

```bash
npm run dev
# or
yarn dev
# or
pnpm dev
# or
bun dev
```

Open [http://localhost:3000](http://localhost:3000) with your browser to see the result.

You can start editing the page by modifying `app/page.tsx`. The page auto-updates as you edit the file.

This project uses [`next/font`](https://nextjs.org/docs/app/building-your-application/optimizing/fonts) to automatically optimize and load [Geist](https://vercel.com/font), a new font family for Vercel.

## Learn More

To learn more about Next.js, take a look at the following resources:

- [Next.js Documentation](https://nextjs.org/docs) - learn about Next.js features and API.
- [Learn Next.js](https://nextjs.org/learn) - an interactive Next.js tutorial.

You can check out [the Next.js GitHub repository](https://github.com/vercel/next.js) - your feedback and contributions are welcome!

app/layout.tsx.name: layout.tsx
app/layout.tsx.upperLevelSummary: This file defines the root layout for a Next.js application, specifically a calculator project. It serves as the top-level wrapper for all pages, establishing the essential HTML document structure including the <html> and <body> tags. The file integrates custom Google Fonts (Geist Sans and Geist Mono) using CSS variables for consistent typography across the site and imports global CSS styles. Additionally, it defines the application's metadata for SEO purposes, setting the page title and description. The RootLayout component acts as a high-order component that ensures these styles and configurations are inherited by all child components within the app directory.
app/layout.tsx.lowerLevelSummary: This file defines the root layout for a Next.js application, specifically a calculator project. It serves as the top-level wrapper for all pages, establishing the essential HTML document structure including the <html> and <body> tags. The file integrates custom Google Fonts (Geist Sans and Geist Mono) using CSS variables for consistent typography across the site and imports global CSS styles. Additionally, it defines the application's metadata for SEO purposes, setting the page title and description. The RootLayout component acts as a high-order component that ensures these styles and configurations are inherited by all child components within the app directory.

structure.name: Font Configuration
structure.summary: Initializes the Geist and Geist_Mono fonts from next/font/google. It configures them to use the 'latin' subset and assigns them to CSS variables (--font-geist-sans and --font-geist-mono) for use throughout the application's styling.

structure.name: metadata
structure.summary: Exports a Metadata object that defines the static SEO properties for the application, including the document title ('Calculator | Nexhacks Sample') and a description.

structure.name: RootLayout
structure.summary: The main layout component that wraps all page content. It renders the base HTML structure, sets the language to English, and applies the font CSS variables to the body element via className. It accepts and renders 'children' as its primary content.

app/page.tsx.name: page.tsx

metadata.fileDocstring:
*
 * Home page component
 * Renders the calculator in a centered layout

app/page.tsx.upperLevelSummary: This file serves as the main entry point for the application's home page, utilizing Next.js's App Router structure. It defines the 'Home' React component, which acts as a top-level container for the user interface. The component imports and renders a custom 'Calculator' component within a semantic 'main' HTML element, applying CSS module styles for layout and presentation. Its primary role is to provide the structural foundation and title for the calculator application, ensuring the content is centered and styled correctly according to the associated stylesheet.
app/page.tsx.lowerLevelSummary: This file serves as the main entry point for the application's home page, utilizing Next.js's App Router structure. It defines the 'Home' React component, which acts as a top-level container for the user interface. The component imports and renders a custom 'Calculator' component within a semantic 'main' HTML element, applying CSS module styles for layout and presentation. Its primary role is to provide the structural foundation and title for the calculator application, ensuring the content is centered and styled correctly according to the associated stylesheet.

structure.name: Home
structure.summary: The default export function that defines the Home page UI. It renders a semantic 'main' element using styles from page.module.css, containing a title heading and the imported Calculator component. It serves as the root layout for the calculator feature.

components/Button.tsx.name: Button.tsx
components/Button.tsx.upperLevelSummary: This file defines a reusable Button React component specifically designed for a calculator application. It utilizes TypeScript for type safety via the ButtonProps interface, defining properties for button labels, click handlers, visual variants (number, operator, special, equals), and layout options (wide). The component dynamically constructs CSS classes using CSS modules based on the provided props, ensuring modular styling. Its primary role is to handle user interactions and emit the button's value back to a parent container via a callback function.
components/Button.tsx.lowerLevelSummary: This file defines a reusable Button React component specifically designed for a calculator application. It utilizes TypeScript for type safety via the ButtonProps interface, defining properties for button labels, click handlers, visual variants (number, operator, special, equals), and layout options (wide). The component dynamically constructs CSS classes using CSS modules based on the provided props, ensuring modular styling. Its primary role is to handle user interactions and emit the button's value back to a parent container via a callback function.

structure.name: ButtonProps
structure.summary: Defines the TypeScript interface for the component's props, specifying the button label (value), the click callback function, visual styling variants, and an optional wide flag for layout flexibility.

structure.name: Button
structure.summary: The main functional component that renders a HTML button element. It manages the click event mapping and dynamically calculates the CSS classes based on the 'variant' and 'wide' props.

structure.name: handleClick
structure.summary: An internal event handler that wraps the provided onClick prop, passing the button's specific value back to the parent component when the button is clicked.

structure.name: classNames calculation
structure.summary: A logic block that assembles an array of CSS module classes, filtering out falsy values and joining them into a single string to apply multiple styles to the button element.

components/ButtonGrid.tsx.name: ButtonGrid.tsx

metadata.firstNLines:
import Button from "./Button";
import styles from "./ButtonGrid.module.css";

interface ButtonGridProps {
    onButtonClick: (value: string) => void;
}

/**
 * Calculator button grid component
 * Arranges buttons in a 4x5 grid layout
 */
export default function ButtonGrid({ onButtonClick }: ButtonGridProps) {
    const buttons = [
        { value: "C", variant: "special" as const },
        { value: "±", variant: "special" as const },
        { value: "%", variant: "special" as const },
        { value: "÷", variant: "operator" as const },
        { value: "7", variant: "number" as const },
        { value: "8", variant: "number" as const },
        { value: "9", variant: "number" as const },
        { value: "×", variant: "operator" as const },
        { value: "4", variant: "number" as const },
        { value: "5", variant: "number" as const },
        { value: "6", variant: "number" as const },
        { value: "-", variant: "operator" as const },
        { value: "1", variant: "number" as const },
        { value: "2", variant: "number" as const },
        { value: "3", variant: "number" as const },
        { value: "+", variant: "operator" as const },
        { value: "0", variant: "number" as const, wide: true },

components/ButtonGrid.tsx.upperLevelSummary: The ButtonGrid component serves as the structural layout for a calculator's keypad, organizing individual Button components into a grid pattern. It defines a static configuration array containing the labels, visual variants (special, operator, number, equals), and layout properties (like width) for each button. By mapping through this data, it dynamically instantiates Button components and passes down a shared click handler, facilitating user interaction for the calculator application. The component uses CSS modules for styling the grid container and relies on a separate Button component for individual button rendering.
components/ButtonGrid.tsx.lowerLevelSummary: The ButtonGrid component serves as the structural layout for a calculator's keypad, organizing individual Button components into a grid pattern. It defines a static configuration array containing the labels, visual variants (special, operator, number, equals), and layout properties (like width) for each button. By mapping through this data, it dynamically instantiates Button components and passes down a shared click handler, facilitating user interaction for the calculator application. The component uses CSS modules for styling the grid container and relies on a separate Button component for individual button rendering.

structure.name: ButtonGridProps
structure.summary: TypeScript interface defining the component's props, specifically requiring an onButtonClick callback function that accepts a string value.

structure.name: ButtonGrid
structure.summary: The main functional component that initializes the calculator button configuration and renders the grid UI.

structure.name: buttons
structure.summary: A static array of objects defining the metadata for each calculator button, including its label, UI variant for styling, and layout flags like 'wide'.

structure.name: JSX Return
structure.summary: The rendering logic that maps over the buttons array to produce a collection of Button components wrapped in a styled div container.

components/Calculator.tsx.name: Calculator.tsx
components/Calculator.tsx.upperLevelSummary: The Calculator component is a client-side React component that serves as the primary controller for a web-based calculator. It manages internal states for the current display, previous numerical values, active mathematical operations, and calculation history. The component leverages several memoized callbacks (useCallback) to handle user interactions such as digit entry, operator selection, and specialized functions like clearing state or calculating percentages. It acts as a bridge between the presentation layer (Display and ButtonGrid components) and the core calculation logic imported from a utility library, ensuring that the UI remains synchronized with the underlying mathematical state machine.
components/Calculator.tsx.lowerLevelSummary: The Calculator component is a client-side React component that serves as the primary controller for a web-based calculator. It manages internal states for the current display, previous numerical values, active mathematical operations, and calculation history. The component leverages several memoized callbacks (useCallback) to handle user interactions such as digit entry, operator selection, and specialized functions like clearing state or calculating percentages. It acts as a bridge between the presentation layer (Display and ButtonGrid components) and the core calculation logic imported from a utility library, ensuring that the UI remains synchronized with the underlying mathematical state machine.

structure.name: Calculator
structure.summary: The main functional component that initializes state hooks for the calculator's operation and renders the layout consisting of a Display and a ButtonGrid.

structure.name: handleNumber
structure.summary: Processes numeric input, either appending the digit to the current display or replacing it if the calculator is waiting for a new operand.

structure.name: handleDecimal
structure.summary: Appends a decimal point to the current display value, ensuring only one decimal exists and handling cases where a decimal starts a new operand.

structure.name: handleOperator
structure.summary: Handles the selection of arithmetic operators. It performs intermediate calculations if an operation is already pending and updates the history and previous value states.

structure.name: handleEquals
structure.summary: Executes the final calculation based on the stored previous value, the selected operator, and the current display value. It updates the display with the result and resets the operation state.

structure.name: handleClear
structure.summary: Resets all component states (display, previousValue, operation, history) to their initial default values.

structure.name: handleBackspace
structure.summary: Removes the last character from the display string, reverting to '0' if the string becomes empty or only contains a minus sign.

structure.name: handleToggleSign
structure.summary: Negates the current numeric value on the display by parsing it, multiplying by -1, and reformatting it.

structure.name: handlePercent
structure.summary: Converts the current display value into a percentage by dividing it by 100.

structure.name: handleButtonClick
structure.summary: A dispatcher function that receives a string value from the ButtonGrid and routes it to the appropriate specific handler function using a switch statement.

components/Display.tsx.name: Display.tsx
components/Display.tsx.upperLevelSummary: The Display.tsx file defines a React functional component named Display designed for a calculator application. It serves as the visual interface for presenting the current input value and the preceding calculation history to the user. The component leverages TypeScript for type safety through the DisplayProps interface and utilizes CSS Modules for encapsulated styling. It is a stateless presentational component that receives its data via props and renders two distinct div elements to separate the history from the current result.
components/Display.tsx.lowerLevelSummary: The Display.tsx file defines a React functional component named Display designed for a calculator application. It serves as the visual interface for presenting the current input value and the preceding calculation history to the user. The component leverages TypeScript for type safety through the DisplayProps interface and utilizes CSS Modules for encapsulated styling. It is a stateless presentational component that receives its data via props and renders two distinct div elements to separate the history from the current result.

structure.name: DisplayProps
structure.summary: A TypeScript interface that defines the shape of the props object, requiring 'value' and 'history' strings to ensure type safety for the component's inputs.

structure.name: Display
structure.summary: The primary functional component that renders the calculator's display UI. It maps the 'history' and 'value' props to specific styled div elements to provide a clear visual distinction between past operations and the current input.

lib/calculator.ts.name: calculator.ts

metadata.fileDocstring:
*
 * Calculator logic module
 * Contains pure mathematical functions for calculator operations

functionSignatures.name: add
functionSignatures.signature: export function add(a: number, b: number): number

functionSignatures.name: subtract
functionSignatures.signature: export function subtract(a: number, b: number): number

functionSignatures.name: multiply
functionSignatures.signature: export function multiply(a: number, b: number): number

functionSignatures.name: divide
functionSignatures.signature: export function divide(a: number, b: number): number

functionSignatures.name: calculate
functionSignatures.signature: export function calculate(a: number, operation: Operation, b: number): number

lib/calculator.ts.upperLevelSummary: This module serves as the core computational engine for a calculator application, providing a set of pure functions for arithmetic operations and data transformation. It implements basic mathematical logic for addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division—the latter including explicit error handling for division by zero. Beyond raw calculations, the file includes a centralized 'calculate' dispatcher that maps operational symbols to their respective functions, a robust input parser that handles non-numeric strings by defaulting to zero, and a display formatter that manages numerical precision and scientific notation for extreme values to ensure a clean user interface.
lib/calculator.ts.lowerLevelSummary: This module serves as the core computational engine for a calculator application, providing a set of pure functions for arithmetic operations and data transformation. It implements basic mathematical logic for addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division—the latter including explicit error handling for division by zero. Beyond raw calculations, the file includes a centralized 'calculate' dispatcher that maps operational symbols to their respective functions, a robust input parser that handles non-numeric strings by defaulting to zero, and a display formatter that manages numerical precision and scientific notation for extreme values to ensure a clean user interface.

structure.name: add
structure.summary: Performs basic addition of two numeric operands and returns the sum.

structure.name: subtract
structure.summary: Calculates the difference between two numbers by subtracting the second operand from the first.

structure.name: multiply
structure.summary: Computes the product of two numeric operands.

structure.name: divide
structure.summary: Divides the first operand by the second, including a safety check that throws an error if the divisor is zero.

structure.name: Operation
structure.summary: Defines a TypeScript union type representing the valid string symbols for calculator operations (+, -, ×, ÷).

structure.name: calculate
structure.summary: Acts as a high-level dispatcher that accepts two operands and an Operation type, routing them to the appropriate mathematical function via a switch statement.

structure.name: parseInput
structure.summary: Safely converts string input into a floating-point number, returning 0 if the input is not a valid number (NaN).

structure.name: formatDisplay
structure.summary: Prepares numeric values for UI display by applying scientific notation for extremely large/small numbers and limiting precision for long decimal strings.

next-env.d.ts.name: next-env.d.ts
next-env.d.ts.upperLevelSummary: This file is a TypeScript declaration file (d.ts) automatically generated and managed by Next.js. Its primary role is to ensure that the TypeScript compiler recognizes Next.js-specific types, global image definitions, and dynamically generated route types. It facilitates type safety and IDE autocompletion for Next.js features such as the App Router, image optimization, and static/dynamic routing. The file acts as a configuration bridge, linking the project's source code to the internal type definitions provided by the Next.js framework and its build artifacts.
next-env.d.ts.lowerLevelSummary: This file is a TypeScript declaration file (d.ts) automatically generated and managed by Next.js. Its primary role is to ensure that the TypeScript compiler recognizes Next.js-specific types, global image definitions, and dynamically generated route types. It facilitates type safety and IDE autocompletion for Next.js features such as the App Router, image optimization, and static/dynamic routing. The file acts as a configuration bridge, linking the project's source code to the internal type definitions provided by the Next.js framework and its build artifacts.

structure.name: Type Reference Directives
structure.summary: Includes triple-slash directives that reference the core Next.js type definitions and global image types, allowing TypeScript to recognize Next.js-specific globals and asset imports.

structure.name: Route Type Import
structure.summary: Imports autogenerated route types from the .next directory. This enables statically typed routing, ensuring that links and navigation within the application adhere to existing file-based routes.

structure.name: Maintenance Notice
structure.summary: A comment block advising developers not to manually edit this file, as it is overwritten by the Next.js CLI during the development or build process.

next.config.ts.name: next.config.ts
next.config.ts.upperLevelSummary: This file serves as the primary configuration entry point for a Next.js application using TypeScript. It imports the 'NextConfig' type definition to provide static type checking and IntelliSense for the configuration object. The 'nextConfig' constant is initialized as an empty object intended to store framework-specific settings such as environment variables, build-time optimizations, redirect rules, and experimental features. By exporting this object as the default, the Next.js build system can consume these settings to customize the application's runtime and compilation behavior.
next.config.ts.lowerLevelSummary: This file serves as the primary configuration entry point for a Next.js application using TypeScript. It imports the 'NextConfig' type definition to provide static type checking and IntelliSense for the configuration object. The 'nextConfig' constant is initialized as an empty object intended to store framework-specific settings such as environment variables, build-time optimizations, redirect rules, and experimental features. By exporting this object as the default, the Next.js build system can consume these settings to customize the application's runtime and compilation behavior.

structure.name: Imports
structure.summary: Imports the NextConfig type from the 'next' package to ensure the configuration object adheres to the expected schema and provides developer tooling support.

structure.name: nextConfig
structure.summary: Defines a constant named nextConfig of type NextConfig. This object is currently a placeholder where developers can add specific Next.js configuration options like image domains, custom headers, or build-time environment variables.

structure.name: Export
structure.summary: Performs a default export of the nextConfig object, making it available for the Next.js framework to load during the server startup or build process.

metadata.firstNLines:
{
  "compilerOptions": {
    "target": "ES2017",
    "lib": ["dom", "dom.iterable", "esnext"],
    "allowJs": true,
    "skipLibCheck": true,
    "strict": true,
    "noEmit": true,
    "esModuleInterop": true,
    "module": "esnext",
    "moduleResolution": "bundler",
    "resolveJsonModule": true,
    "isolatedModules": true,
    "jsx": "react-jsx",
    "incremental": true,
    "plugins": [
      {
        "name": "next"
      }
    ],
    "paths": {
      "@/*": ["./*"]
    }
  },
  "include": [
    "next-env.d.ts",
    "**/*.ts",
    "**/*.tsx",
    ".next/types/**/*.ts",
    ".next/dev/types/**/*.ts",

..name: calculator
..summary: This directory serves as the root of a TypeScript-based Next.js application. It manages project-wide configurations and orchestrates core functionality through application routes, reusable UI components, and shared utility libraries.

app.name: app
app.summary: This directory serves as the application's root entry point, defining the foundational structure and global styling for the project. It manages the top-level layout and metadata while hosting the main page's core calculator interface.

components.name: components
components.summary: This directory houses the modular UI components and CSS modules required to build a functional calculator interface. Key functionalities include centralized state orchestration, a history-tracking display, and a structured grid of interactive input buttons.

lib.name: lib
lib.summary:
1. This directory serves as a dependency-free logic layer providing core mathematical and utility functions.
2. It implements essential modules for arithmetic operations, input parsing, and display formatting.
